description: There was lots of aurora activity seen in the UK in 2024 and there is likely to be even more this year.
title: Why the aurora dazzled in 2024 and what 2025 has in store
title_page: Why the aurora dazzled in 2024 and what 2025 has in store - BBC Weather
maintext:
For most of us the chance to see the aurora is just a bucket list wish involving costly travel to the Arctic Circle and then not always getting the big reward.
However, in 2024, the lights were visible unusually far south, with people reporting stunning sightings across southern England on multiple occasions.
Featuring a kaleidoscope of reds, greens, purples and blues, and with even a rare STEVE phenomenon putting in an appearance, it was best year for these spectacles for 20 years.
And the good news is this looks likely to continue into 2025.
The main reason why the lights have been so dazzling is because we are at a peak in the Sun's 11-year cycle of activity which will continue into 2025.
During this peak there is an increase in the number of eruptions from the Sun, including solar flares and coronal mass ejections.
These send powerful bursts of energy and material into space, causing - amongst other things - the aurora that we see from Earth.
